solution.text:
Here the maximum class frequency is _{k}_,
And,
The class corresponding to this frequency is 30 - 40.
So, the modal class is 30 - 40.
Now
Modal class = 30 - 40, lower limit (l ) of modal class = 30,
class size (h) = 10
frequency ( \(f_1\) ) of the modal class = _{k}_,
frequency ( \(f_0\) ) of class preceding the modal class = _{j}_,
frequency ( \(f_2\) ) of class succeeding the modal class = _{l}_.
Now, let us substitute these values in the formula :
Mode = l + (\((f_1-f_0)\over (2*f_1-f_0-f_2)\))*h
Mode = 30 + (\((_{k}_-_{j}_)\over (2*_{k}_-_{j}_-_{l}_)\))*10
Mode = 30 + \(_{{k-j}}_\over _{{(2*k)-j-l}}_\)*10
Mode = 30 + (_{{trunc((Decimal(k)-j)/((2*k)-j-l),3)}}_)*10
Mode = 30 + (_{{trunc(((Decimal(k)-j)/((2*k)-j-l))*10,3)}}_)
Mode = _{{trunc((30+((Decimal(k)-j)/((2*k)-j-l))*10),3)}}_

content.text:
A Society's guard noted down the no. of cars leaving the society everyday for _{{i+j+k+l+m}}_ days.Following table contains the data collected by the guard.Find the mode of given data.
\begin{array}{c|lcr} No. of cars & \text{10-20} & \text{20-30} & \text{30-40} & \text{40-50} & \text{50-60} \\ \hline \ Days & _{i}_ & _{j}_ & _{k}_ & _{l}_ & _{m}_ \\ \hline\end{array}
